entry.title: Dad Test!

Author: StarlaStar64

Rating: Teen And Up AudiencesLanguage: EnglishWords: 10,428Chapters: 1/1Kudos: 100

Summary: The first time it happens, Bruce doesn’t do a great job at hiding his surprise. It was only a couple weeks after Tim’s adoption was officially finalized - hyphenated name and all. Bruce still smiles to himself at the memory of reading ‘Timothy Jackson Drake-Wayne’ on those papers, trying not to choke up at his third son being the first to take the Wayne name. Of course that was never an expectation, but still, it meant something that Tim chose to take it.With that considered, perhaps Bruce shouldn’t have been quite so shocked by the teen calling him ‘Dad’, but he is. entry.title: Bearing the Pain
entry.summary:
Author: aerascreamer

Rating: Teen And Up AudiencesLanguage: EnglishWords: 6,156Chapters: 2/7Kudos: 12

Summary: The twelfth birthday of a child is one of the most important in their life, as they will finally be able to shift for the first time into their animal form.But sometimes, things don’t go as expected.Maybe it is genetics, maybe it is a physical issue, or maybe it is trauma, but some children aren't able to shift at all either for years or even for life.As Bruce reaches his twelfth birthday, he not only has to face this milestone without his parents who died years ago, but he also learns he is shiftless. And the high society of Gotham does not take kindly to shiftless individuals.Now, how will he deal with this fact? How is life as a shiftless person? Will he learn to be ok with it? Will it influence his relationships with his family?As time goes by, Bruce's family grew bigger despite the tragedy that struck him in his youth, and the man does his best given his condition to be there for them.

entry.title: What a Bittersweet Christmas
entry.summary:
Author: Amur_adonis1731

Rating: General AudiencesLanguage: EnglishWords: 2,803Chapters: 1/1Kudos: 22

Summary: Bruce Wayne, ever the emotionally constipated man, sat in his chair.It wasn’t his chair at W.E. where he ditzed, himbo’d, and Brucie’d his way through social calls, fooling every soul into falling for his outgoing, peacock-like persona.It wasn’t his chair in the Batcave, where he analyzed the trails of long-forgotten cold cases or a string of messy murder scenes, maintaining his broody, self-sacrificing, and ever-so-paranoid bat vigilante persona for colleagues, media, and family alike.It wasn’t his chair in his sitting room, where he was often found on slow mornings, usually nursing a steaming cup of green tea and sat on the worn leather couch with the latest edition of the New York Times crossword, word search, or other puzzle, opening himself to his family and friends with the simple offer of space and Bruce.It was, instead, a chair in his study, where only his family was permitted to enter—a safe space and a haven of silence, away from the bustle of people and the rush of crime.
